messages.subject: File - SHQ_intro.txt
messages.msgSnippet: Hello and welcome to the wonderful world of SHQ---Shinsengumi Headquarters! This is our discussion list for the sharing and gathering of info related to the
messages.messageBody:
Hello and welcome to the wonderful world of SHQ---Shinsengumi Headquarters!

This is our discussion list for the sharing and gathering of info related to the Shinsengumi, its memebrs and their life and times. We cover many incarnations of the Miburo from fact to fiction, film, televison, anime and manga, video games--pretty much anythi nand everything.

I hope all new members will take a moment to introduce themselves and of course ALL members old and new are ENCOURAGED and INVITED to participate and bring up topics for discussion.

Below you will find links to our related communities.

The Website
http://www.shinsengumihq.com

The Messageboard .
http://www.shinsengumiMB.com

The Database
http://www.shinsengumiDB.com

The Fanfiction/Fanart list
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/SHQ_Spy_Division/

So what are ya waiting for jump in and talk to us!

messages.messageBody:
There are several speculations on Yamanami's reason to leave the Shinsengumi. Officially,
it is still a mystery, even though a disagreement in philosophy on top of a rivalry with
Hijikata is the most accepted theory. There's also a theory that Yamanami committed
suicide without ever leaving the Shinsengumi.


~Seven

messages.subject: Re: [SHQ] Re: konbanwa mina san !!!
messages.msgSnippet: ... Shinsengumi was paid, but they weren t paid a great deal. Receiving reward money from the Emperor for, say, distinguished service at the 8.18.1863
messages.messageBody:
> But, in "MibuGishiDen", why they look so poor ???

Shinsengumi was paid, but they weren't paid a great deal. Receiving reward
money from the Emperor for, say, distinguished service at the 8.18.1863
incident, or the Ikedaya incident, was a big thing-- THAT was big money.
Another issue to bear in mind is that these men started out poor, so even if
they received a lot of money, they wouldn't go about making themselves *not*
look poor right away.

Later on, when they were paid by the Shogunate, they also weren't paid an
incredibly high amount...but they were better off than before (this appears
in Mibugishiden-- the Shinsengumi go through "bakushin toritate"-- which
means they are made hatamoto, or retainers of the Shogun). The best off the
Shinsengumi were going to be monetarily and status-wise, at least on paper,
was right before they headed to fight the Imperial army in Kai Province.
Kondou was to become a daimyo with a 100,000 koku income, Hijikata would
have 50,000, the captains would have 30,000, and the junior officers 10,000
(see page 102 of Kikuchi Akira's "Toba-Fushimi no Tatakai Kara Nagareyama
Made," in "Saitou Hajime no Subete) However, this was never to become
reality.

> Could anybody tell me, except "Kiyokawa Hachirou/Serizawa Kamo's probs",
>are there another >internal problem in Shinsengumi????

Yes. There were periodically issues with people leaving. Also, early on,
there was the issue of Okura Isetake, Arakida Samanosuke, and Kusunoki
Kojuro, the Choshu spies who joined Shinsengumi early on, and were killed in
the fall of 1863. (see Itou Tetsuya's timeline which appears at the end of
the book "Saitou Hajime no Subete".) Most famous is the incident of Itou
Kashitarou's group leaving-- this would later come back to haunt Kondou, who
was shot by the survivors of the group in early 1868 (see page 157 of
Nagakura Shinpachi's "Shinsengumi Tenmatsuki"). Another survivor of that
group, Kano Washio, was the man who positively identified the newly captured
Kondou later that year. Here is a picture of him:
http://www.dokidoki.ne.jp/home2/quwatoro/syashin/kanou.jpg

There were also many other people who were executed for various reasons.
However, Nagakura records even those who were executed on the memorial that
he inscribed for Shinsengumi, a translation of which appears here:
http://www.shinsengumihq.com/ShinsengumiMonument.htm

I hope that helps answer your questions.

-M.

messages.subject: Re: konbanwa mina san !!!
messages.msgSnippet: ... yakuza era, I d say that ... samurai class and the yakuza. ... Seven, yakuza connections with the ultranationalists began more openly in the 1890s with
messages.messageBody:
--- In SHQ@yahoogroups.com, "Seven" <nlf7@...> wrote:
> Rather than saying that the Shinsengumi has a connection with
yakuza era, I'd say that
> there's a connection between the ultranationalists from the
samurai class and the yakuza.
> I recommend
>
> JAPAN'S DARK BACKGROUND 1881-1945
> http://www.fortunecity.com/tatooine/leiber/50/bds1.htm
>
>
> ~Seven


Seven, yakuza connections with the ultranationalists began
more "openly" in the 1890s with the changing face of political
parties during the Meiji era. Yakuza today still are considered to
be right wing conservatives and use their money to support political
candidates.

Rei Shinoda was asking about the *Bakumatsu era, during which the
yakuza had flourished (they were also doing very well much earlier).
As stated in my post, yakuza "history" mostly lore, goes way back in
the past.

Yakuza, samurai and politicians also had common ground in very high
profile martial arts societies as well during the Meiji (which had
members from the military and police).

The quote posted at http://www.shinsengumihq.com/misc_facts.htm

Seymour, Christopher. Yakuza Diary
Atlantic Monthly Press ISBN: 087113604X

"Tells of the origins of the Aizu-Kotetsu gang which traced its
roots to the birth of its first leader Senkichi in 1836. "Isao
Kondo" was the leader of "Shinsei-gumi" and he needed to place
redundant members of the Shinsengumi. These men were incorporated
into the gang was formally established in 1888 and used the name
Aizu-Kotetsu. Aizu was their native region and Kotetsu was the
favored brand/type of sword of the boss." (Seymour 70-72)

again, I'm sure Seymour who had heard this lore from a member of the
yakuza cannot guarantee its accuracy. As I mentioned in my post,
there were practical reasons why the Shinsengumi *may have sought to
be on good terms with the powerful yakuza which in fact did run the
red-light district (the shinsengumi patrol area). Yakuza families
mimicked samurai and merchant families and often had blood line
lineages where the "business" was passed onto the oldest son (unless
he is overthrown).

messages.messageBody:
Ah, I forgot to post a message with the scans, didn't I? I've been reading more about the
Ichimura brothers.

There are a few theories in regard of Ichimura Tetsunosuke's death date, while many
believe that Ichimura joined Saigo Takamori's army and died during the Satsuma Rebellion
in 1877, some believe that he died from an illness in 1873.

The uploaded scans support the latter theory.

-----------------------------

Rather than saying that the Shinsengumi has a connection with yakuza era, I'd say that
there's a connection between the ultranationalists from the samurai class and the yakuza.
I recommend

JAPAN'S DARK BACKGROUND 1881-1945
http://www.fortunecity.com/tatooine/leiber/50/bds1.htm


~Seven



--- In SHQ@yahoogroups.com, "secretary" <secretarytocapt3@...> wrote:
>
> Thank you to Seven for uploading those scans for the community
>
> To answer the questions...
>
> > 1. Why Shinsengumi choosed the word "makoto" ?
> A very very general essay on "makoto" is here
> http://www.shinsengumihq.com/definitionsofmakoto.htm
>
> Makoto to one's lord (boss)
> Makoto to one's land (han/domain/feud)
> Makoto to one's teacher (either martial, educational, art,
> philosophical or one who has given you a means to make a living such
> as someone who teaches you how to be a swordsmith)
> Makoto to one's self
> Sincerity is water which flows from one's heart, it is inexhaustible
> and gives life.
>
> I've never read a step by step account as to how Kondou Isami or
> other prominent figures in the Shinsengumi may have concluded to
> adopt this term---however keep in mind that people across the
> political spectrum also drew on this word frequently such
> as "loyalty/sincerity to the emperor".
> -----------------------------
> > 3. Does Shinsengumi has a connection with yakuza era ?
>
> Shinsengumi and Yakuza connection is mentioned here please click
> on "Books Which Mention the Shinsengumi"
> http://www.shinsengumihq.com/misc_facts.htm
>
> You may say "NO WAY, the Shinsengumi should not mess with those scum!"
> however, way way way in the past...yakuza have existed for a very
> long time serving as almost its own social class which ends up being
> an economic safety net for ronin, social misfits and outcasts.
> Yakuza not surprisingly rose in power alongside the merchant class
> during the end of the Edo Era. There were also divisions and
> specific labels for yakuza as well. The term "yakuza" is very
> general.
>
> More importantly, yakuza ran the red light district for a long time
> before the Shinsengumi were even born. When you think of yakuza try
> not to picture "modern" yakuza. Ofcourse historically, there were
> flashy dressing thug yakuza on the street too. HOwever, the ones who
> had "real" power acted....like RESPECTABLE SAMURAI OR MERCHANT
> FAMILIES (*_*). Some people colleted artwork depicting samurai
> (often actors portraying samurai)---some also collect artwork
> depicting famous yakuza who became "folk heroes"---thus from a social
> point of view, yakuza were at times viewed as Robin HOod type
> figures.
>
> I think that -if- the Shinsengumi had more deeper ties with the
> yakuza it would be because yakuza are information brokers. If the
> Shinsengumi wished to be successful in their jobs they would try to
> be on good terms with the yakuza and even buy information from the
> yakuza. From the Edo Era, Meiji and modern era, yakuza and law
> enforcement have sought a strange "balance of power". If that
> delicate arrangement is disturbed one or the other side would take
> action.
>

messages.subject: Re: konbanwa mina san !!!
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you to Seven for uploading those scans for the community To answer the questions... ... A very very general essay on makoto is here
messages.messageBody:
Thank you to Seven for uploading those scans for the community

To answer the questions...

> 1. Why Shinsengumi choosed the word "makoto" ?
A very very general essay on "makoto" is here
http://www.shinsengumihq.com/definitionsofmakoto.htm

Makoto to one's lord (boss)
Makoto to one's land (han/domain/feud)
Makoto to one's teacher (either martial, educational, art,
philosophical or one who has given you a means to make a living such
as someone who teaches you how to be a swordsmith)
Makoto to one's self
Sincerity is water which flows from one's heart, it is inexhaustible
and gives life.

I've never read a step by step account as to how Kondou Isami or
other prominent figures in the Shinsengumi may have concluded to
adopt this term---however keep in mind that people across the
political spectrum also drew on this word frequently such
as "loyalty/sincerity to the emperor".
-----------------------------
> 3. Does Shinsengumi has a connection with yakuza era ?

Shinsengumi and Yakuza connection is mentioned here please click
on "Books Which Mention the Shinsengumi"
http://www.shinsengumihq.com/misc_facts.htm

You may say "NO WAY, the Shinsengumi should not mess with those scum!"
however, way way way in the past...yakuza have existed for a very
long time serving as almost its own social class which ends up being
an economic safety net for ronin, social misfits and outcasts.
Yakuza not surprisingly rose in power alongside the merchant class
during the end of the Edo Era. There were also divisions and
specific labels for yakuza as well. The term "yakuza" is very
general.

More importantly, yakuza ran the red light district for a long time
before the Shinsengumi were even born. When you think of yakuza try
not to picture "modern" yakuza. Ofcourse historically, there were
flashy dressing thug yakuza on the street too. HOwever, the ones who
had "real" power acted....like RESPECTABLE SAMURAI OR MERCHANT
FAMILIES (*_*). Some people colleted artwork depicting samurai
(often actors portraying samurai)---some also collect artwork
depicting famous yakuza who became "folk heroes"---thus from a social
point of view, yakuza were at times viewed as Robin HOod type
figures.

I think that -if- the Shinsengumi had more deeper ties with the
yakuza it would be because yakuza are information brokers. If the
Shinsengumi wished to be successful in their jobs they would try to
be on good terms with the yakuza and even buy information from the
yakuza. From the Edo Era, Meiji and modern era, yakuza and law
enforcement have sought a strange "balance of power". If that
delicate arrangement is disturbed one or the other side would take
action.

I recommend Yakuza: Japan's Criminal Underworld, Expanded Edition
by David E. Kaplan (Author), Alec Dubro
Yakuza are also mentioned here http://www.shinsengumihq.com/NSNR.htm
-----------------------------
> 4. Is it wrong if I say "makoto" was Shinsengumi way of life /
philosophy?

You can say it was an ideal the group adopted---but like all "ways of
life" ultimately the individual decides how he can interpret it.
-----------------------------
> 5. ( Just for the people who love Shinsengumi ),, Would you ( if
you don't mind ) give me your private reasons why you love them ?

I grew interested in the Shinsengumi from the anime/manga Rurouni
Kenshin. Later I became fascinated with the historical Saitou Hajime
(Fujita Goro) and the larger Aizu narrative.
I owe alot to the Shinsengumi for teaching me about bias:
1) from people who are pro Ishin and Meiji revisionist texts
2) from Shinsengumi fans who romanticized the Miburo and try to white
wash them
3) people who confuse history with fiction and the subsequent
disillusionment with all things
4) I like the "free" expressions of creativity I see in Shinsengumi
fandom---I especially like original works
5) I've never really researched stuff like this before---so I picked
up alot of neat little tricks to find stuff in the library etc etc

Although now I focus on history (because I cannot afford manga/anime)
I still do alot of fanfic writing and drawing although I don't
subject the public to those efforts (^___^)

messages.subject: RE: [SHQ] konbanwa mina san !!!
messages.msgSnippet: ... As I feel I m best qualified to give an answer to numbers 2 and 3, that s what I ll do. First and foremost let me say-- you can t separate Shinsengumi s
messages.messageBody:
> 2. Why Shinsengumi was so loyal to the bakufu ? ( i'm not asking to the
>Aizu clan )
> 3. Does Shinsengumi has a connection with yakuza era ?

As I feel I'm best qualified to give an answer to numbers 2 and 3, that's
what I'll do.

First and foremost let me say-- you can't separate Shinsengumi's "loyalty"
into "sections" so easily. Aizu was ordered by the Bakufu to take charge of
the Shinsengumi. Ultimately the Bakufu was above everything in terms of
administrative structure, and in terms of "who ran the show," they were it.
However, this functioned *through* Aizu. The Bakufu issued orders to Aizu to
take charge of the group of men who became Shinsengumi-- almost like a
"guardian" might take charge of an orphan (these orders can be seen in
"Kyoto Shugoshoku Shimatsu", which is the work of Saitou Hajime's
acquaintance Yamakawa Hiroshi). It was Bakufu money, but Aizu supervision.
Without Aizu, this group of men becomes almost no different from any other
ronin walking the streets of Kyoto. The big sign you see in most depictions
of the Shinsengumi's headquarters reads something like "By Authority of Lord
Aizu, Protector of Kyoto"--- this can be compared to a British box of cereal
or detergent (I've seen them with my own eyes, so I know) having a little
inscription that reads "By Appointment to Her Majesty the Queen". By having
that added bit of authority, Shinsengumi sets itself apart from the other
ronin wandering the streets of Kyoto, who mainly couldn't openly say that
they had the patronage of so-and-so.

Still with me? Good!

Now, with the "no legitimacy without Aizu" concept being the case, you do
have a point in talking about "loyalty to the Bakufu". This is because
ultimately, the legitimacy that Aizu gives Shinsengumi is merely the
Shogun's legitimacy, for which Aizu acts as a conduit. After all, it was by
order of the Shogunate that Aizu came to Kyoto, and without that legitimacy,
Aizu also doesn't have much authority in Kyoto. A medium sized domain from
the middle of nowhere in northeastern Japan? No way it'd be able to do
anything without the legitimacy of the central government!

So if you think of "legitimacy" as being like a flow of water, the flow
starts with the Bakufu, flows *through* the pipe or conduit (Aizu), and
reaches its destination (Shinsengumi).

As for your question about the Shinsengumi's loyalty to the Bakufu-- the
answer is that it wasn't rigidly loyal. Yes, it stuck with Tokugawa forces
to the end, but there's more to it than that. Kondou Isami, toward the end
of his time in Kyoto, was in frequent contact with Goto Shojiro-- a man of
Tosa-- and apparently professed great admiration for the man, though they
only met once. Even the Bakufu officials were not rigid-- they met with men
of Tosa and Satsuma. Case in point-- Ryoma-- yes, *that* Ryoma-- warned the
Shogunate that Satsuma was planning to have its way by force. Nagai Genba
(information on whom appears on the SHQ site and who had frequent contact
with Shinsengumi), in the name of the Shogunate, met with Ryoma face to
face-- and even arranged for Goto Shojiro's meeting with Kondou.

Now, that still doesn't answer your question, I know, but stay with me,
because I'm about to get to that.

As I said earlier, in the beginning of its short history, Shinsengumi was
basically nothing without Aizu acting as a conduit for the Bakufu legitimacy
to flow to it. Now, after a certain point (roughly 1866), this was to
change, and *that* is where it is appropriate to ask "Why was the
Shinsengumi so loyal to the Bakufu?" The reason for this is that in that
time period, the Bakufu's gorojuu-shuu (Senior Councilors, basically Cabinet
Ministers for the Shogun) signed a document that made the Shinsengumi
"bakushin"-- Bakufu retainers ("bakufu no gokerai-tachi," in simpler
Japanese). The ranks of "bakushin" include such men as Enomoto Takeaki,
Nagai Genba, Otori Keisuke, and Katsu Kaishu (ALL directly involved with
Shinsengumi on a face-to-face basis)-- and all these men owe EVERYTHING to
the Bakufu. They get paid by the Bakufu, they get their authority and jobs
from the Bakufu, and everything they do is affected by the fact that they
serve the Bakufu.

So at that point-- why was the Shinsengumi so loyal to the Bakufu? The
answer is: the same way that someone getting paid for working in a company
might be loyal to that company-- because without that position, he has no
job, no money, his family will starve, and so on.

Shinsengumi was defeated at Toba-Fushimi and fled to Edo in early 1868. Why
did they stick with the now *former* Bakufu? Part of it was because of their
implication (however false or contrived) in the murder of Sakamoto Ryoma
(which even a work as incomplete and shallow as Romulus Hillsborough's
"Shinsengumi" talks about, citing primary data), and part of it was because
they had nowhere else to go.

This continued, from the time where the senior Shinsengumi men could have
become daimyo (the "Koyochinbutai period," I'll call it), then Aizu, then
Sendai, then Hakodate...they stuck with the Bakufu forces and the northern
clans because, well...what awaited them pretty much anywhere else was death.

Now, as to your question about "are the Shinsengumi connected to Yakuza?"
the answer lies in the Yakuza boss known as "Aizu no Kotetsu". This man, who
if I recall correctly at one time worked in the Aizu mansion in Edo (hence
his nickname), was a major presence in the underworld of Kyoto. While I
don't have much data on him, I know for a fact that after Toba-Fushimi, he
buried the Aizu and Kuwana dead (when no one else would or was even allowed
to), paying for the burials out of his own pocket. Since Shinsengumi were
among the Aizu dead, I believe it is safe to assume that he buried his fair
share of Shinsengumi dead, too. Secretarytocapt3 has had more experience
researching the Yakuza than I have, so perhaps she would further explore
this topic.

I hope I've been able to answer things to some extent. While I'm basing my
views on the primary data I've read (Meiji-era newspapers, journals,
government documents), as well as the secondary data (books by historians),
you should NOT have to take my word at face value...try to look for things
on your own, and never be afraid to question "why?". Ever. It's by
questioning things that historians get stuff done.

-M.

messages.subject: konbanwa mina san !!!
messages.msgSnippet: Hualllowww mina san !! Rei to moushimasu. cOULD ANYBODY HELP MEE ?? Tasuketekurenaaaai ??? Plzzzz !! I wanna ask a some questions, n hope somebody will answer
messages.messageBody:
Hualllowww mina san !!
Rei to moushimasu.
cOULD ANYBODY HELP MEE ??
Tasuketekurenaaaai ??? Plzzzz !!

I wanna ask a some questions, n hope somebody will answer it -_-;;

1. Why Shinsengumi choosed the word "makoto" ?
( What does it mean to them ? )
2. Why Shinsengumi was so loyal to the bakufu ? ( i'm not asking to the Aizu clan )
3. Does Shinsengumi has a connection with yakuza era ?
( Since Yakuza no hitobito mo was also ronin nanode.... )
4. Is it wrong if I say "makoto" was Shinsengumi way of life / philosophy?
5. ( Just for the people who love Shinsengumi ),, Would you ( if you don't mind ) give me your private reasons why you love them ?

Thx 4 the answer !!! B'coz It's so important 4 me,..
Nazenara...Watashi wa Shinsengumi ni tsuite ronbun o kaiteiru dakara ^.~
( Watashi mo Shinsengumi ni MUCHUU desuyo. They've already got my heart and I raise my glass for them. Even I know nothing bout them T.T )

Doumo arigatou gozaimashita !!!

messages.msgSnippet: Hello and welcome to the wonderful world of SHQ---Shinsengumi Headquarters! This is our discussion list for the sharing and gathering of info related to the
messages.messageBody:
Hello and welcome to the wonderful world of SHQ---Shinsengumi Headquarters!

This is our discussion list for the sharing and gathering of info related to the Shinsengumi, its memebrs and their life and times. We cover many incarnations of the Miburo from fact to fiction, film, televison, anime and manga, video games--pretty much anythi nand everything.

I hope all new members will take a moment to introduce themselves and of course ALL members old and new are ENCOURAGED and INVITED to participate and bring up topics for discussion.

Below you will find links to our related communities.

The Website
http://www.shinsengumihq.com

The Messageboard .
http://www.shinsengumiMB.com

The Database
http://www.shinsengumiDB.com

The Fanfiction/Fanart list
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/SHQ_Spy_Division/

So what are ya waiting for jump in and talk to us!

Hello and welcome to the wonderful world of SHQ---Shinsengumi Headquarters!

This is our discussion list for the sharing and gathering of info related to the Shinsengumi, its memebrs and their life and times. We cover many incarnations of the Miburo from fact to fiction, film, televison, anime and manga, video games--pretty much anythi nand everything.

I hope all new members will take a moment to introduce themselves and of course ALL members old and new are ENCOURAGED and INVITED to participate and bring up topics for discussion.

Below you will find links to our related communities.

The Website
http://www.shinsengumihq.com

The Messageboard .
http://www.shinsengumiMB.com

The Database
http://www.shinsengumiDB.com

The Fanfiction/Fanart list
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/SHQ_Spy_Division/

So what are ya waiting for jump in and talk to us!
